results.title: Existentialism > Notes (Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy/Summer 2020 Edition)
results.snippet: 18. As we saw (note 3 above) Alasdair MacIntyre argues that existentialism is just disappointed rationalism and that its hyperbolic rhetoric stems from its failure to abandon various foundationalist assumptions.

results.title: Patriotism (Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy)
results.snippet: In his seminal lecture “Is Patriotism a Virtue?” Alasdair MacIntyre contrasts patriotism with the liberal commitment to certain universal values and principles.

results.title: Patriotism (Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy/Winter 2016 Edition)
results.snippet: The beginning of this change was marked by Andrew Oldenquist's account of morality as a matter of various loyalties, rather than abstract principles and ideals (Oldenquist 1982), and Alasdair MacIntyre's argument that patriotism is a central moral virtue (MacIntyre 1984).

results.title: Philosophy of Education (Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy/Winter 2025 Edition)
results.snippet: MacIntyre insisted that teaching is not a practice, others mostly disagreed, but the lesson of the debate is arguably that MacIntyre’s way of distinguishing “internal” and “external” goods obscured the relationships between the inherent goods or aims of education—goods or aims without which it would not be education—and the further goods or purposes that might be achieved through education (Hager 2011).

results.title: The Natural Law Tradition in Ethics (Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy)
results.snippet: Alasdair MacIntyre has argued, for example, that the first precepts of the natural law are to be understood as those that make possible communal inquiry into the nature of the good: both the positive and the negative precepts are enabling rules, norms that enable humans to engage in common ...
